alternative_title: What do to when an employee dies because of an accident at work
body:
$!Workplace deaths must always be reported to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) or the Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland (HSENI).$!

If a member of staff dies while at work you must report the death to the:
	
- [police](/contact-police "Contact the police") (except in Northern Ireland)
-  the [Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland (HSENI)](http://www.hseni.gov.uk/contact-us/report-an-incident.htm "Contact the Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland online"){:rel="external"}
- Health and Safety Executive (HSE) - England, Wales and Scotland only

$C 
**HSE Incident Contact Centre**  
0845 300 9923  
Monday to Friday, 8:30am to 5pm  
$C

You must report any deaths or serious injuries, even if the employee is working off-site at the time. 

##Outstanding salary and other payments

You must make all outstanding payments when an employee dies. This includes:
	
- calculating and paying their final salary and any other outstanding payments
- calculating and making any deductions for tax and NICs (National Insurance contributions)	

There's more information on the payroll tasks you have to do on the [HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) website.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/employees/changes/death.htm "payroll tasks when an employee dies"){:rel="external"}

^Payments to a person who has died are usually made to the executor of that person's estate.^

*[HSE]: Health and Safety Executive
*[HSENI]: Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland 
*[NICs]: National Insurance contributions
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
overview: If an employee dies at work, you must report the death to the Health and Safety Executive and the police
title: What to do when an employee dies
